reasoning: The critique targets the position’s “strongest-link” rebuttal (counterargument #7): the idea that you can route around compute bottlenecks by choosing an alternative progress path. That point is supportive but not strictly necessary for the overall conclusion (which also rests on arguments about long-run substitutability, experiment efficiency, extrapolation issues, etc.), so centrality is moderate. The critique’s main move—arguing that purportedly distinct routes may share common compute-intensive prerequisites (frontier models, large-scale evals, tuning, synthetic data generation, red-teaming), so route-shopping doesn’t escape a fixed compute budget—is a real and relevant challenge, but it is not a full refutation: it doesn’t establish that *all* meaningful routes are tightly coupled to the same compute bottleneck, nor quantify the degree of correlation or show that modest-compute paths are implausible. Its factual claims are broadly plausible (these activities typically are compute-demanding), though somewhat speculative in universality and magnitude. It is clearly stated, tightly focused, and has little to no filler.
title: Strongest-link progress claims fail when all routes share compute-intensive dependencies
